Dear Cody Akers:
Attached is the Interim Inspection Report for the above referenced agency completed on
October 23, 2024. Due to the violations of applicable licensing rules, a written corrective
action plan is required. The corrective action plan is due 15 days from the date of this letter
and must include the following:
• For any repeat violations, why the prior corrective action plan did not result in compliance.
• How compliance with each citation will be achieved.
• Who is directly responsible for implementing the action steps in the corrective action plan.
• Specific time frames for each citation as to when the correction will be completed or
implemented.
• How continuing compliance will be maintained once compliance is achieved.
• The signature of the responsible party and a date.
If you fail to submit an acceptable corrective action plan, disciplinary action may result.
Please review the enclosed documentation for accuracy and contact me with any
questions. In the event that I am not available, and you need to speak to someone
immediately, please contact the area manager Jessica VandenHeuvel at 616-204-6992.
Sincerely,
Shannon (Shay) Mavis

III. DESCRIPTION OF FINDINGS
The agency is in compliance with all applicable rules and statutes except for the following:
CCI Rule 400.4113 Employee records.
(1) An institution shall maintain employee records
for each employee and shall include
documentation of all of the following information
prior to employment or at the time specified in
this rule:
(i) Documentation from the Michigan
department of human services, the equivalent
state or Canadian provincial agency, or
equivalent agency in the country where the
person usually resides, that the person has
not been determined to be a perpetrator of
child abuse or child neglect. The
documentation shall be completed not more
than 30 days prior to the start of employment
and every 12 months thereafter.
Four of sixty-one new employee files did not have a central registry clearance
completed within 30 days prior to hire.
Repeat Violation Established
SIR #2024SIC0001273 dated 4/19/24; CAP approved 5/28/24
CCI Rule 400.4155 Institutions not detention institutions or shelter care
institutions; initial treatment plan
(1) The social service worker shall complete, sign,
and date an initial treatment plan for each resident
within 30 calendar days of admission.
One of three open youth files reviewed had an initial treatment service plan
completed 5 days late.
IV. TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE
The agency was offered technical assistance in the following areas:
• Variable interval checks need to occur even if a youth is on precautions for
10 minutes checks.
• Make sure if a staff has a hyphenated last name, CR and criminal are run
for the hyphenated last name, as well as the singular last names/aliases.

V. CONSULTATION
The facility did not require any consultation.
VI. EVALUATION OF RENEWAL PERIOD
Maltreatment in Care
There were no substantiated incidents of maltreatment in care during this licensing
period.
Corrective Action Plan Compliance
The agency has submitted 5 acceptable corrective action plans (CAP) during this
licensing period, and compliance with each individual CAP is as follows:
All CAPs during the period of review were a result of violations found during special
investigations.
- SIR #2024C0000969SI (dated 1/10/24; CAP approved 1/22/24). The facility had
a violation for Rule 109(1)(c) Program Statement as a staff at the facility
completed a safety check on a youth while in the shower, which was a violation
of the facility’s Resident Safety Checks Policy. As a result, the staff member
received corrective action. In addition, the safety checks policy and rights of
recipients policy were reviewed at a staff meeting. Resident safety checks
procedure was added to initial staff orientation as well as discussed monthly at
each staff meeting for 6 months.
- SIR #2024C0000996SI (dated 1/24/24; CAP approved 2/6/24). The facility had
a repeat violation for Rule 109(1)(c) Program Statement as the facility used a
gurney for a youth when they did not have a policy or procedure for the use of a
gurney. As a result, a policy was established stating a gurney/stretcher is not to
be used with the facility’s youth. It was reviewed at staff meetings monthly.
- SIR #2024C0001157SI (dated 3/5/24; CAP approved 3/28/24). The facility had
a repeat violation for Rule 109(1)(c) Program Statement as a staff at the facility
used inappropriate language and engaged in inappropriate conversation with a
youth. As a result, the staff member involved received corrective action and met
with the Chief Administrator to review the facility’s Code of Ethical Conduct &
Standards as well as the Staff-Client Relationships Policy. In addition, the
policies were discussed with all staff at the next staff meeting.
- SIR #2024SIC0001273 (dated 4/19/24; CAP approved 5/28/24). The facility had
violations for Rule 113(1)(i) Employee Records: Central Registry Clearances,
Rule 113(1)(e) Employee Records: References, and Rule 128(1)(a)(b) Initial
and Ongoing Staff Training. The facility was found in non-compliance due to
having hospital staff reporting and completing restraints for youth in the
program, but the hospital staff did not meet the hiring requirements for licensing.
As a result, the facility updated clearances for hospital staff, completed a
4

variance for references for non-Lotus specific staff (approved by DCWL), and
established a one-hour orientation for non-Lotus specific staff (approved in
variance by DCWL).
- SIR #2024SIC0001379 (dated 6/20/24; CAP approved 8/23/24). The facility had
violations for Rule 158(1)(a)(ii) Intervention Standards and Prohibitions due to a
staff restraining a youth inappropriately as well as Rule 163(5) Incident
Reporting due to the facility not completing the incident report timely. As a
result, the restraint model was discussed & re-education was completed during
team meetings in July, a one-on-one training session on the restraint model was
completed with the staff involved, and improved internal practices related to
entering/approving restraint incident reports timely.
Financial Overview
The facility's budget and financial audit were reviewed, and there were no concerns
with the facility's financial status.
PREA compliance (if applicable)
Not Applicable
Chief Administrator Assessment
Chief Administrator (CA) reported continued staff education through 2-hour monthly
staff meetings as well as three separate 1 hour long virtual team meetings three
times per month have been largely beneficial for the program. CA reported the
change in their restraint policy to eliminate the need to end restraint episodes after
14 minutes 59 seconds (even if a youth was still escalated) has largely reduced the
number of restraints the program has had. CA reported it has also been helpful to
split youth amongst the different pods to reduce escalations due to peer conflicts or
aggression. CA reported they are seeing successful outcomes for youth in their
program. CA reported they have a great team of staff who are committed and
dedicated to youth success.
Staff and Youth Interviews
Staff reported initial and ongoing trainings are very helpful for their positions. They
reported they have a very supportive environment, and supervisors, managers and
staff are amazing. They reported they are updated on policy and procedure
changes, and communication is excellent. There were no concerns noted during
staff interviews.
Youth reported they feel safe at the facility. They reported they get enough food,
but don't always like the food provided. They reported they enjoy the sensory
rooms, visits with family and outings with staff. They feel staff are very supportive
5

and really care about them. There were no concerns noted during interviews with
youth.
Description of Agency Walk Through
A walkthrough of the facility occurred on 10/23/24 and there were no concerns
noted. Only two out of the four pods are currently being utilized for youth.
VII. RECOMMENDATION
Based on inspection findings the agency is not in compliance with all applicable licensing
statutes and rules. Upon receipt of an acceptable corrective action plan, it is
recommended that the agency continue on their regular license.
